title: A strange place to contemplate a turbulent world
text:
For Australia, these and other events presage an inflection point. Our key relationships are not, currently, in a state of flux, but Scott Morrison has signalled a distinctive approach for dealing with such a turbulent world, one with similarities to the Howard and Menzies eras.

Scott Morrison: "We can never answer to a higher authority." AAP

In an address to a Lowy Institute dinner at Sydney Town Hall on Thursday night, he effectively queried a strong UN role in setting global policies to combat climate change and international protocols for allowing in refugees. Both are sensitive issues. The intra-Coalition climate change culture wars – pitting moderates against climate change denialists – played a significant role in the downfall of Mr Morrison’s predecessor, Malcolm Turnbull.

More than a year later, Mr Morrison told his Lowy Institute audience: “We should avoid any reflex towards a negative globalism that coercively seeks to impose a mandate from an often ill-defined, borderless global community. Only a national government, especially one accountable through the ballot box and the rule of law, can define its national interests. We can never answer to a higher authority than the people of Australia.”

While he briefly acknowledged Australia had played its part in building a more constructive world order through “co-operative and respectful internationalism”, he warned that pragmatic international engagement was being pushed aside by a new order that sought to "elevate global institutions above the authority of nation states to direct international policies".

Morrison’s foreign policy speech agenda contrasts with Labor, which has a long history of support for international covenants, particularly those framed by the UN. This dates back to the UN’s founding conference in San Francisco in 1945, when Australia’s then Foreign Minister, Dr H. V. (Doc) Evatt, was elected the new body’s inaugural president and made the cover of Time Magazine.

Rarely as punchy

The Menzies government was more "Morrisonian" in its approach, although its language was rarely as punchy. However, it was subjected to numerous international rhetorical touch-ups over its strict adherence to the White Australia at various UN forums.

Advertisement

Australia’s biggest era of global engagement was during the Whitlam Labor government years of 1972-75. It used a series of UN covenants covering the environment and human rights to assert a more international approach to issues and at the same time use the new powers to enforce a more centralised legal regime in Australia.

Nearly three quarters of a century after the UN San Francisco conference, Mr Morrison averred that “the world works best” when “the character and distinctiveness of independent nations is preserved within a framework of mutual respect”. This puts him firmly in the Howard-Menzies tradition, but the world has changed since then.

Australia’s foreign policy challenges, like dealing with Washington and Beijing as they engage in a protean power struggle, are more complex and difficult. Further, his "nations first, UN last" approach sits uneasily beside his repeated call for China to abide by largely Western-mandated international trade rules and submit to its WTO status being changed from a developing to a fully developed economy.

Unrest in Hong Kong remains a big distraction for China. Getty

Morrison was delivering his Lowy Institute address not only as the US and UK are afflicted by political turmoil, but China, the third man in in this equation, is not immune, either. On the same day it displayed its military might in a 70th annual National Day show of force in Beijing, police shot a teenage protester in Hong Kong, and the former British Crown colony continues to be racked by unrest.

Meanwhile, back at Bob’s Market in LA’s Echo Park, late night clues about its wider significance for Australia begin arriving in the unlikely form of hot-rod cars. They perform a series of illegal "donuts" on the traffic island with tyres screeching, then speed off into the night, leaving behind a maze of black skid marks.

It’s their way of paying homage to The Fast and The Furious, an American action movie, TV series, live performance and comic book franchise that features a petrol-head’s giddy brew of illegal street car racing, heists and spies. Iconic early scenes in The Fast and The Furious were shot in and around Bob’s Market – hence the unusual late-night homage paid by LA’s legion of hot-rod street racing aficionados.

The first of many Fast and Furious films was released in 2001 and the last is slotted for 2021. It’s a nice little earner, too. Various Fast and Furious products have so far generated $US5 billion ($7.4 billion) in revenue for Universal Pictures.

Advertisement

This nightly ritual at Bob’s Market illustrates the grip of American popular culture. Rev-heads doing donuts in empty streets in Australian cities and country towns are common occurrences, as they are elsewhere. In fact, US popular culture is so embedded in the psyche of people in other countries that the original source for the influence is rarely acknowledged.

American movies have grabbed our imagination, going back to the founding of the first suburban cinemas in Australia in the '20s – from Charlie Chaplin to Hedy Lamarr. This popular culture invasion was accompanied by the jazz Age – Afro-American music that enthralled the world with its improvisation and syncopated rhythmic patterns.

Since the war, those US movies, TV series, hit songs, rhythm and blues, jazz, casual clothes like blue jeans, fast food, and the gym craze, have spread far and wide. Collectively, they have moulded much of the world into America’s image. Of course, elsewhere there is Shakespeare and Schopenhauer, Mozart and Modigliani, and countless others, but the US influence on global popular culture is undeniable.

The question being asked in Canberra is pretty much this: 'What does it mean for Australia?'

At such an uncertain time in world events, it’s worth pondering the significance of US popular culture as a factor in Australia’s foreign relations. The issue arises as a grumpy President Donald Trump thrashes around over the decision of the Democrat-controlled House of Representatives to launch an impeachment inquiry, the first step in a drawn-out process that could lead to Trump being forced out of office.

As claims and counter claims come thick and fast in Washington, the question being asked in Canberra is pretty much this: "What does it mean for Australia?" So far, the answers have focused on issues like whether the US will continue to be a major power in the western Pacific, will China overtake America in economic strength within 10-20 years, as many have forecast, and so on.

But the question never addressed is the role that US popular culture has in cementing our alliance with the US, an alliance that dramatically came into force as the Japanese military stormed through south-east Asia in early 1942, threatening Australia.

According to the latest Lowy Institute poll, 52 per cent of respondents said they trusted the US to “do the right thing” in world affairs, compared with only 32 per cent for China. The US figure is relatively low compared with earlier surveys, but still much higher than China’s, even during the rancorous unpredictability of the Trump administration.

Advertisement

The gap in local public perceptions of the US compared with China widens when just 30 per cent of respondents said they trusted China’s all-powerful leader, President Xi Jinping, to do the right thing.

More recently, a Newspoll survey found that 56 per cent of respondents believe the relationship with the US is more important than ties with China, despite the enormous trade links with the Middle Kingdom. This compares with just one quarter of respondents who believe China should take priority.

Erratic behaviour

The usual explanation trotted out for public support for the US ties is the long security alliance, the fact that both countries are democracies, both are former British colonies, and have long-established connections through universities, think tanks, government departments and scientific organisations.

At a time of growing local alarm about the erratic behaviour of the White House incumbent, however, this explanation may be valid but it’s limited. Ties are also underwritten by the popular cultural connection. China may have a rich history in calligraphy, silks, highly stylised painting of rural scenes, crockery and food. But Peking Opera just doesn’t cut it against B.B. King, Aretha Franklin, Bruce Springsteen, Alicia Keys, Chuck Berry and Lana Del Ray.

And that’s before those rev-heads start doing donuts opposite Bob’s Market in Echo Park, LA.
description: Bob’s Market, a classic American general store facing a large traffic island in a run-down Los Angeles neighbourhood called Echo Park, is a bizarre place to start exploring the state of Australia’s foreign relations.
